Literature Review: The viral protein U (Vpu) encoded by human and simian immunodeficiency viruses (HIVs and SIVs) is a small yet highly versatile accessory protein that plays a pivotal role in viral pathogenesis and immune evasion. Despite its non-essential nature for viral replication in cell culture, Vpu has been shown to significantly enhance viral spread and infectivity in vivo through a variety of mechanisms. This literature review aims to consolidate current understanding of Vpu's multifunctional roles, focusing on its interactions with host cellular factors and its implications for viral fitness and immune evasion.One of the most well-characterized functions of Vpu is its ability to counteract the host restriction factor tetherin (BST-2/CD317), which inhibits the release of viral particles from infected cells. Vpu achieves this by downregulating tetherin from the cell surface, thereby promoting the efficient release of fully infectious viral particles (Neil et al., 2008). This mechanism is crucial for the spread of HIV-1 in vivo, highlighting Vpu's importance in viral pathogenesis.In addition to its role in tetherin antagonism, Vpu is involved in the degradation of the primary viral receptor CD4. By targeting CD4 for proteasomal degradation, Vpu prevents superinfection and facilitates the release of viral particles by reducing the levels of CD4 on the cell surface (Margottin et al., 1998). This dual role of Vpu in enhancing viral release and preventing superinfection underscores its significance in the viral life cycle.Recent studies have expanded our understanding of Vpu's functions by revealing its involvement in modulating the host immune response. Vpu has been shown to inhibit the activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB), a key regulator of innate immunity and inflammation (Akari et al., 2000). By suppressing NF-κB activation, Vpu dampens the host's antiviral response, thereby facilitating viral persistence and replication.Moreover, Vpu has been implicated in the modulation of DNA damage repair mechanisms. It has been demonstrated that Vpu can promote the degradation of nuclear viral complementary DNA in productively infected cells, thereby preventing the accumulation of viral DNA and reducing the risk of superinfection (Sauter et al., 2015). This novel function of Vpu adds another layer to its role in viral immune evasion and highlights its complexity as an accessory protein.The multifunctional nature of Vpu is further exemplified by its ability to interact with a variety of host cellular factors, including those involved in protein trafficking, immune signaling, and cell cycle regulation. These interactions not only facilitate Vpu's primary functions but also contribute to its role in enhancing viral fitness and immune evasion (Strebel et al., 2009).In conclusion, Vpu is a small but highly versatile viral accessory protein that plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of HIV-1 and closely related SIVs. Through its interactions with host cellular factors, Vpu enhances viral release, prevents superinfection, modulates the immune response, and promotes viral persistence. The continued study of Vpu's functions and mechanisms of action will provide valuable insights into viral pathogenesis and may inform the development of novel antiviral strategies.
